chunk_summary.summary: Motivation and overview. Discrete-time models with small inter-tick time are used to approximate continuous-time price dynamics. A simple discrete model with constant growth (μ) and noise (σ) leads to log-normal marginals under both the real measure P and the risk-neutral (martingale) measure Q. The Black–Scholes formula can be derived heuristically from this approximation.

Model specification. The model is parameterized by inter-tick time δt and three constants: noise σ, stock growth μ, and risk-free rate r. The cash bond is B_t = exp(r t). The stock moves on a recombining tree: from s it goes to s·exp(μ δt + σ √(δt)) on an up-jump and to s·exp(μ δt - σ √(δt)) on a down-jump. Up and down jumps are equally likely (p = 1/2).

Distributional limit as ticks become frequent. For fixed horizon t, let n = t/δt and let X_n be the number of up-jumps in n steps. Then S_t can be written in terms of X_n. X_n ~ Binomial(n,1/2) with mean n/2 and variance n/4 so the normalized variable (2X_n - n)/√n has mean 0 and variance 1. By the Central Limit Theorem this converges to N(0,1) as n→∞, yielding log S_t ~ Normal(log S_0 + μ t, σ^2 t) — i.e. S_t becomes log-normal.

key_definitions.definition: δt — the discrete time increment between successive price updates; the model is intended to approximate continuous time as δt → 0.
σ — parameter controlling the magnitude of random upward/downward multiplicative shocks at each tick.
μ — deterministic drift per unit time applied multiplicatively in each tick.
r — continuously compounded risk-free rate used to price the cash bond and for risk-neutral adjustments.
B_t = exp(r t) — the deterministic growth of the riskless asset.
From node value s at a tick of length δt, the next value is s·exp(μ δt + σ √(δt)) on an up-jump and s·exp(μ δt - σ √(δt)) on a down-jump.
For horizon t set n = t/δt. X_n = number of up-jumps among the n independent Bernoulli steps (each with p = 1/2 under P).

theorems.name: Central Limit Theorem (applied)
theorems.statement: For X_n ~ Binomial(n,1/2), the normalized variable (2 X_n - n)/√n converges in distribution to N(0,1) as n → ∞.
theorems.role_in_text: Used to justify that the discrete multiplicative model's log-returns converge to a normal distribution when the number of ticks n grows (δt → 0), implying S_t becomes log-normal with variance scaling σ^2 t.

equations.meaning: Value of the riskless cash bond at time t (continuous compounding).
equations.intuition: Deterministic exponential growth at rate r; used for discounting and to define the martingale/risk-neutral measure.

equations.latex: s_{\text{up}} = s \exp(\mu\,\delta t + \sigma\sqrt{\delta t}), \quad s_{\text{down}} = s \exp(\mu\,\delta t - \sigma\sqrt{\delta t})
equations.meaning: Multiplicative update rules for the stock price at one tick: up and down outcomes.
equations.intuition: Each tick applies a deterministic drift μ δt and a symmetric ±random shock of size σ√(δt) in the exponent so jumps multiplicatively and recombine across paths.

equations.meaning: Under the original measure P each up or down jump is equally likely.
equations.intuition: Simple symmetric Bernoulli step for the discrete model's noise component.

equations.latex: n = t/\delta t, \quad X_n = \text{number of up-jumps in } n \text{ steps}
equations.meaning: Definition of number of discrete steps n and the count of up moves X_n over horizon t.
equations.intuition: Relates the discrete-time model to a fixed continuous horizon by counting ticks.

equations.meaning: Expression of the terminal stock price after n steps in terms of X_n.
equations.intuition: Separates deterministic drift μ t from the aggregated random contribution: the normalized sum (2X_n-n)/√n captures standardized net up-moves and scales with σ√t.

equations.latex: \mathbb{E}[X_n] = n/2, \quad \operatorname{Var}(X_n) = n/4, \quad \Rightarrow \frac{2X_n - n}{\sqrt{n}} \text{ has mean }0\text{ and variance }1
equations.meaning: Moments of the binomial up-count and the standardized variable used in the CLT.
equations.intuition: Shows the normalized aggregate noise has unit variance and zero mean, preparing for Gaussian approximation.

equations.meaning: Limit distribution of log-price as δt → 0 (n → ∞): normal with mean log S_0 + μ t and variance σ^2 t.
equations.intuition: By CLT, the discrete-time log-returns aggregate to a Gaussian process; hence the stock becomes log-normal marginally, matching the geometric Brownian motion marginal law.

figures.description: Title slide 'Overture to continuous models' with bullets summarizing motivation: discrete techniques approximate continuous models, leads to log-normal under P and Q, connection to Black–Scholes.
figures.significance: Sets context and objectives: motivate passing from discrete trees to continuous-time option pricing models.

figures.description: Slide 'Model with constant stock growth and noise' listing model parameters (δt, σ, μ, r), cash bond formula, per-tick up/down multiplicative updates, and p=1/2.
figures.significance: Specifies the discrete-time multiplicative model that will be used to approximate continuous dynamics.

figures.description: Slide 'Model with constant stock growth and noise, continued' deriving S_t in terms of X_n, stating binomial moments and invoking the Central Limit Theorem to conclude log-normality of S_t as δt → 0.
figures.significance: Provides the probabilistic derivation (via CLT) that the discrete model's log-price converges to a normal distribution, yielding log-normal stock prices in the limit.

chunk_summary.scope: Slides 4-6 (Under the martingale measure; continuation; Pricing a call option)
main_points: Compute the martingale (risk-neutral) probability q for the discrete up/down model and approximate it for small inter-tick time δt.
Under the martingale measure Q the binomial-count statistic (2X_n - n)/√n has a nonzero mean (drift adjustment) but variance → 1; by the Central Limit Theorem it converges to a normal variable.

Consequently, under Q the asset price S_t is asymptotically log-normal with log-mean log S_0 + (r - 1/2 σ^2) t and variance σ^2 t; equivalently S_t = S_0 exp(σ √t Z + (r - 1/2 σ^2) t) with Z ~ N(0,1) under Q.
The time-0 no-arbitrage price of a European call X = (S_T - k)^+ is the discounted Q-expectation E_Q[B_T^{-1} X], which leads to the Black–Scholes closed-form formula involving standard normal cdf Φ.
structure: Slide 4: formula for q and its small-δt approximation; implication that X_n under Q is binomial with mean n q and variance n q (1-q).
Slide 5: asymptotic mean and variance of (2X_n - n)/√n under Q, CLT application, log-normal marginal distribution of S_t under Q with explicit representation involving Z ~ N(0,1).
Slide 6: expression for discounted payoff expectation and the Black–Scholes formula for a European call price.

q.meaning: The risk-neutral (martingale) probability of an up-jump in the discrete up/down model.
q.notes: For small inter-tick time δt this is approximated to shift the physical probability p to a risk-neutral one.

X_n.meaning: Number of up-jumps in n independent up/down steps (binomial random variable).
X_n.notes: Under P it has mean n/2 (when p=1/2); under Q it has mean n q and variance n q (1-q).

S_t (under Q).meaning: Asymptotic (marginal) log-normal distribution of the asset price at time t under the risk-neutral measure Q.
S_t (under Q).notes: Drift equals risk-free rate r (after the 1/2 σ^2 correction) consistent with risk-neutral pricing.

B_t.meaning: Cash bond (riskless asset) evolving at continuously compounded rate r.
B_t.notes: Used to discount payoffs when computing Q-expectations.

Z.meaning: Standard normal random variable N(0,1) under Q emerging from CLT limit of the normalized binomial count.
Z.notes: Represents the Gaussian noise in the continuous-time log-normal model.

Call payoff X.meaning: Payoff at maturity T of a European call option with strike k.
Call payoff X.notes: Price at t=0 is E_Q[B_T^{-1} X] by risk-neutral valuation.

theorems.name: Central Limit Theorem (applied)
theorems.statement: The normalized sum (or normalized binomial-count statistic) converges in distribution to a normal random variable as the number of steps n→∞ (equivalently δt→0 with t fixed).
theorems.role_in_chunk: Used to conclude that (2X_n - n)/√n converges to a normal variable (with a drift under Q), which yields the log-normal limit for S_t under Q.

theorems.name: Risk-neutral (martingale) pricing principle
theorems.statement: In an arbitrage-free model there exists an equivalent martingale measure Q under which discounted asset prices are martingales; derivative prices are given by discounted expectations under Q.
theorems.role_in_chunk: Provides the justification to replace physical probabilities by q, compute the Q-marginal distribution of S_t, and price the call by E_Q[B_T^{-1} X].

equations.meaning: Exact expression for the risk-neutral probability q in a single-step up/down model (ensures discounted expected next price equals current price).
equations.intuition: q is chosen so that the expected discounted stock price under q equals the current price — it shifts physical probabilities to eliminate arbitrage.

equations.meaning: Small-δt approximation of q in terms of model parameters μ, σ and r.
equations.intuition: For very small time-steps the risk-neutral probability deviates slightly from 1/2 by an amount proportional to √{δt} and the excess drift (μ + 1/2 σ^2 − r) scaled by σ.

equations.meaning: Asymptotic distribution (mean and variance) of the normalized up-count under the martingale measure Q.
equations.intuition: Under Q the normalized binomial statistic has a nonzero mean (reflecting the change from P to Q) but unit variance; CLT gives the Gaussian limit.

equations.meaning: Log-normal marginal distribution of the stock price at time t under the risk-neutral measure.
equations.intuition: The discrete up/down model with many small steps converges to geometric Brownian motion marginal — volatility scales as √t and drift becomes r - 1/2 σ^2 under Q.

equations.latex: C_0 = E_Q\big[B_T^{-1}(S_T - k)^+\big] = S_0\Phi(d_1) - k e^{-rT}\Phi(d_2)
equations.meaning: Black–Scholes formula for the time-0 price C_0 of a European call with maturity T and strike k, where d_{1,2} are the usual terms.
equations.intuition: The call price is the discounted risk-neutral expectation of the payoff; integration against the log-normal density yields the closed-form expression with normal cdf Φ.

equations.meaning: The discounted expectation form (integrand) used before evaluating to the closed-form Black–Scholes expression.
equations.intuition: This is the direct risk-neutral expectation of the discounted payoff written in terms of the log-normal representation of S_T.

figures.description: Slide titled 'Under the martingale measure' (first slide). Contains the exact formula for q and its small-δt approximation, and the remark that X_n is binomial with mean n q and variance n q(1-q) under Q.
figures.significance: Introduces the computation of risk-neutral probabilities in the discrete model and prepares for the CLT-based limit under Q.

figures.description: Slide titled 'Under the martingale measure, continued'. States the asymptotic mean and variance of (2X_n - n)/√n under Q, uses the Central Limit Theorem, and gives the log-normal form S_t = S_0 exp(σ√t Z + (r - 1/2 σ^2) t) with Z ~ N(0,1) under Q.
figures.significance: Key slide deriving the continuous-time risk-neutral marginal distribution of the stock via CLT and showing the drift becomes r - 1/2 σ^2 under Q.

figures.description: Slide titled 'Pricing a call option'. Defines the call payoff X = (S_T - k)^+, writes the discounted Q-expectation, and presents the Black–Scholes closed-form formula involving Φ.
figures.significance: Connects the derived risk-neutral log-normal distribution to option pricing and states the Black–Scholes formula as the evaluation of the Q-expectation.
